align verb [I or T]
(STRAIGHT LINE)
to put two or more things into a straight line, or to form a straight line: When you've aligned the notch on the gun with the target, fire! Align the ruler and the middle of the paper and then cut it straight. Make sure the columns align in the chart. Opposite
skew
More examplesFewer examplesThe left eye of the patient and the right eye of the examiner are aligned.The "star in the East", he says, could have been Mars, Jupiter and Saturn aligned in the constellation Pisces on 20 February 6BC.The mounting rails are to be placed at the 25% and 75% positions along the length and have to align with the rafter.

align verb [I or T]
(AGREE)
to be the same or similar, or to agree with each other; to make two things do this: The post was deleted because it did not align with the values of this website. The job of an IT business analyst is to align IT systems with changing business needs. In the first decade of the union, economic growth among member countries was generally aligned.
to agree with or support another person, group, organization, or view: The country's leading intellectuals tend to be aligned with the opposition. As a musician, he aligned himself with the avant-garde. The superpowers force smaller countries to align behind them in rival blocs.
More examplesFewer examplesWe plan to align income tax and national insurance systems for small business.Boys are more self-confident than girls about their maths skills, a finding which aligns with stereotypes of female inferiority in mathematics.A devout Christian, she always compares political policies with what the Bible says and tries to determine if the two align.Schools are ranked on how well they align their educational policies with tough national standards.Should we take existing morality as a given, or should we take skepticism seriously? I align with the latter view.
